text: We'll hear argument next in No. 96-320, Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company v. Michael Buckley.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:
Ms. Birnbaum, may I ask you if you would clarify your position in this case with the one that the... that is being taken by the defendants in the case this afternoon?
What--
We can't both be right.
--Well, I'm not going to argue the Georgene case on the standing issue.
The courts below relied on the physical impact of the fibers going inside his lungs.
--But, first, there is no real evidence of that except a hypothetical given by the expert below.
Well, how do we deal with a physical impact, does that constitute an injury, even if it's slight?
No.

But aren't there many jurisdictions that have recognized a claim for medical monitoring, a common law claim for medical monitoring, for people who have been massively exposed but have not yet manifested any illness?
There are... there are a few.
--How many, roughly, would you say?
--A little less, but there are some.
Yes, but may I interrupt with just a question?
--No.
Even though he'd have to pay his doctor's bill every 6 months?
That would be a damage, but it wouldn't be an injury.
But not within the meaning of the statute?
Right.
But as a matter of ordinary reasoning, would not that be a pecuniary injury that one could at least say gave... gave rise to some kind of claim?
I think it's just much more complicated than that--
Well, it's more complicated because there are 21 million people out there.
--Twenty-one million--
But if you look at just the one is what I'm trying to think of.
--But the problem is, if you had 21 million just asbestos-exposed people--
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Well, how... let's talk about your first point for a minute.
--That's right, Your Honor.
But the first, obviously, doesn't?
Exactly, yes.
Why a grave toxic disease?
Well--
--there are all sorts of risks that we go through in life, and you pay for them out of your own pocket.
--Right.
--is not a bed of roses.
--That's right.
This person is coughing, presumably because he has a cold.
Right.
And I'm very careful about such things.
Absolutely not, Your Honor.
